![img](https://media.giphy.com/media/KK2zmePfOtKOk/giphy.gif)

Yes. We did not consider the `timestamp_format` in Druid side at the first place. Now `DruidDatasource` will not have `timestamp_format` column and before accessing the `datasource.timestamp_format` in viz.py, it will check the type of datasource first and only access it when the type is `table`.
We still keep the `timestamp_format` as a table property because each table mostly has only one column as datetime column (users can choose that column in List Table Column) and that `timestamp_format` will only apply for that chosen column. If a different column with different datetime is chosen, then a new timestamp format should be specified.
We also remove the try catch in migration. It is a leftover when we are testing. :S
Thank you.

I like the idea of improving the error messages but we should allow for both custom message and this introspection of the web response. What about `slice.error` receives both `message` and `response` and we print a nice div (perhaps expandable, with more details) depending on what is provided by the user?
great, thanks

Since Hive does not support a native datetime data type, a lot of our Presto timestamp columns are just ISO text, so this "fix" would break pretty much all of our slices.

The solution is probably in that other PR where you can define your date function on a per-table (but I'm asking the author to move to per-column) basis. Closing, sorry.

I need this too

@XiaodiKong Are you thinking about the actual "metric" names? You can redefine what the Metric names are in the table editing screen. 

So you could take "sum" and name it via the Metric name you even have control over the expression that is grouped, so you could do "sum(somefield) and name it "sum_field" there. 

What I am looking to do with this issue is for fields that just don't "look" pretty (the 1 -> Female, 2 -> Male example) or Lets say you have a field that is an abbreviation for departments in your company:

HR -> Human Resources
Acct -> Accounting
Op -> Operations
IT -> Information Technology

For columns or for metrics, you could attach a "lookup" table that any time the values were displayed, Caravel would try a simple replacement if value to be displayed = "lookup value" than instead replace the value.  

This would have no impact on the SQL, and you wouldn't be able to change how the visualizations compute things, this would be on the labels only.  Additionally, we should probably limit the size of the tables to say "50" for performance reasons. If you have more that 50 values, it would be tedious to create the lookup tables, and you may be better off with a join, I am talking about presentation layer only for this request.  The idea being in the case of the Abbreviations, I could show the vis on a dashboard as is, but if I want it to look really good, then I can alter the final output and get that 100% I am looking for. 

(Also: If no lookup value if found, obviously default to the real value)

Isn't it just Gunicorn timing out when you run long queries?

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/6456002/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/6456002)

Coverage remained the same at 81.856% when pulling **4dd6ec068375fc7ed4f6f085aff4491b8e348b15 on mistercrunch:doc_security** into **5bc50210ad665f3d0348326b49c81d97011b36f3 on airbnb:master**.

That's what is interesting because I'll get that 'worker timeout' typically between 30 - 60 seconds but I've definitely run queries for longer than that without getting a timeout. The other day I looked into it a little more and found that even after I get the error I can run `select * from pg_stat_activity` and see that the worker running my query is still running and usually will run to completion. So it's almost like the connection to the worker from the main app is being lost or something.

I have very little experience with Python web frameworks or gunicorn so it's hard for me to tell where even to look to see what's really going on.
ok, let's that in, as mentioned before we should remove the need for this hack and handle this in `forms.py`.

Thanks. I understand that perm is necessary. The migration of the [version](https://github.com/airbnb/caravel/blob/master/caravel/migrations/versions/c3a8f8611885_materializing_permission.py#L22-L29) will use `models.Slice` class to do the query for the perm in the migration process but at that time the database is not fully migrated yet. If any migration after this one add a new column for slices, the models.Slice class will declare the new column too. Before reaching the new column migration, using models.Slice will cause the SQLAlchemy fail to bind that new column and pop up error "no such column"
Yeah that looks right.

For some reason, Landscape check is not running. This seems to affecting all pull requests right now.

Caravel uses a sqlite database in a temporary folder of the instance it's
running on. You can see the path to it in your caravel_config.py. Check
that this file is persisting when you restart the machine. If you're using
an environment like docker (which rebuilds the instance every time you
start) then the configuration won't persist. Try changing the directory to
a mounted folder, or using an external database (like a MySql server).

@x4base Oh I think I didn't migrate the database right, because I found that there are 26 tables in sqlite3 db, but only 12 tables in MySQL. I check the warnings when I was migrating, it's says that `mysql - #1071 specified key was too long; max key length is 767 bytes` , so there are some table can't load into MySQL, I think that's why I can't upgrade my database. Any solutions? I've checked this [issue](https://github.com/airbnb/caravel/pull/459) , but still confused.
It'd be nice to have an export/import feature that could work across databases, though across versions may be more tricky.

Yes that'd be very nice. Here's a better way to write this sql with 2 scans instead of 3:

```
SELECT COALESCE(b.distributor, 'Others'), sum(admissions) as admissions 
FROM TicketSales ts
LEFT JOIN (
    SELECT TOP 10 distributor FROM TicketSales
    GROUP BY distributor
    ORDER BY sum(admissions) DESC;
) as subq ON ts.distributor = subq.distributor
GROUP BY COALESCE(b.distributor, 'Others')
ORDER BY sum(admissions) DESC;
```

For the "Series Limit" feature we're already doing this essentially, except with an INNER JOIN. Showing "Others" there should be easy-ish. You have to change the join to a left join and do this COALESCE thing.
